item.title: Ticket #1099 (wpautop filter may product invalid markup) updated
item.dc:creator: Jon Leighton (Turnip)
item.description:
Cc changed

Well, here's a patch (kinda). It might need some more elements, and probably needs a bit more testing, but it worked for me... 

	$pee = preg_replace('/\n?(.+?)(?:\n\s*\n|\z)/s', "\t<p>$1</p>\n", $pee); // make paragraphs, including one at the end
+	$pee = preg_replace('!(<(?:div|address|form)[^>]*>)([^<]+)</p>!', "$1<p>$2</p>", $pee);
+	$pee = preg_replace('!<p>([^<]+)\s*?(</(?:div|address|form)[^>]*>)!', "<p>$1</p>$2", $pee);
	$pee = preg_replace('|<p>\s*?</p>|', '', $pee); // under certain strange conditions it could create a P of entirely whitespace

To prevent the invalid markup being produced, I found that at least two newlines were needed between the containing elements's tag (div, address etc.) and the text that needs to be peed. So this would be ok: 

<div>
some words
some more words
</div>

But this wouldn't: 

<div>
some words
some more words
</div>

item.title: Ticket #1282 ("All Comments" feed does not include post titles) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
Version, Severity changed

/wp-commentsrss2.php: 

52c52
<               <title>Comment on <?php the_title_rss($comment->comment_post_ID); ?> by: <?php comment_author_rss() ?></title>
---
>               <title>by: <?php comment_author_rss() ?></title>

wp-includes/feed-functions.php: 

12,13c12,13
< function the_title_rss($id = 0) {
<       $title = get_the_title($id);
---
> function the_title_rss() {
>       $title = get_the_title();

item.title: Ticket #1389 (Human readable information for ins and del quicktags (code attached)) updated
item.dc:creator: revbob
item.description: Do you think we should kick this out into the forums and get a consensus first?

item.title: Ticket #1389 (Human readable information for ins and del quicktags (code attached)) updated
item.dc:creator: revbob
item.description:
Being able to make old <ins> and <del> labels human-readable is quite a benefit. And PHP's date formatting is certainly easier to code than JavaScript's. But your suggestion would require every visitor to the website to execute the code in the plugin, perhaps several times per page, to perform that formatting. Doing it in quicktags.js only requires that work to be done once, at the time the author edits the page. Doing it once is far more attractive to me than doing it (up to) several times a second.

And btw, until relatively recently the datetime data generated by WP was bogus anyway, so I'm not certain how much old information the plugin would be able to read retroactively.

item.title: Ticket #1391 (Allow per-author templates) updated
item.dc:creator: chuyskywalker
item.description: This would best be handled as a plugin. There are plenty of hooks for catching what template is about to be output and changing it up. As an example, â€‹Post Template Plugin will "hook" based on categories to change the file used when displaying a post. Taking that and extending it to "hook" for associated author ID's shouldn't be much of a leap.

item.title: add publish_post, edit_post hooks for xmlrpc posting.diff attached to Ticket #967

item.title: Ticket #1398 (feature request: simple html-tag to signal not formatting posts) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1398 (feature request: simple html-tag to signal not formatting posts) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: I guess it is de facto at least in wikis to have a special html-tag to signal the software not to process post/page content further inside the tag. In wordpress this would mean disabling br ja p tags etc creation/formatting inside that html-tag. Would be easy to implement and occasionally very handy when you just want to copypaste some existing html into posts (to be formatted better later) and current way of converting empty lines to p break the pasted html. I know there are plugins to handle this, but I presume this kind on html tag is quite de facto way to be included..

item.title: Ticket #1397 (comment_max_links discrepency) updated
item.dc:creator: chrisdolan
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1397 (comment_max_links discrepency) created
item.dc:creator: chrisdolan
item.description:
In WP v1.5.1, the Options-Discussion page has an field labeled:

"Hold a comment in the queue if it contains more than N links."

However, it appears that the code enforces this as "more than equal to". This discrepency causes confusion.
